Award.AwardTitle: CREST-PRF: Constraining Spatiotemporal Nutrient Dynamics Along An Arid-Land River Continuum

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Centers of Research Excellence in Science and Technology-Postdoctoral Research Fellowship (CREST-PRF) track within the CREST program supports beginning CREST Center investigators with significant potential and provides them with training and research experiences that will broaden perspectives, facilitate interdisciplinary interactions and establish them in positions of leadership within the scientific community. This CREST-PRF project is aligned with the research focus of the CREST Center for Water and the Environment (CWE) at the University of New Mexico. The objective of this project is to determine how longitudinal changes in the composition of dissolved organic carbon control nutrient uptake dynamics and export in arid-land river networks at multiple spatial (reach to river) and temporal (hours to years) scales. Arid lands support approximately a third of the world's population and half of the world's agriculture. Due to multiple competing stressors (e.g., dams, constant dewatering, fire ash inputs and increased evapotranspiration), and overreliance on water resources, arid-land river systems are typically less resilient and more vulnerable to water quality degradation, including eutrophication. Results from this project will provide tools to assess the fate and transport of carbon and nutrients in arid river systems, and scientific knowledge to support the development of multi-sector solutions aimed at improving nutrient recycling in arid metropolitan areas, within the context of the food, water and energy nexus.

The proposed research will continuously monitor nitrate, phosphate, dissolved organic carbon, and ancillary water quality parameters using state-of-the-art sensor technology for two years along a river continuum spanning four orders of magnitude in mean annual discharge, ~2000 m in altitude and ~500 km of stream length. High-information-yield experiments to quantify carbon and nutrient uptake rates will be conducted every three weeks at the sensor sites along with laboratory analysis of dissolved organic carbon composition. The research approach harnesses the power of "big data" by combining continuous sensor data, field experiments, and laboratory measurements with time-series analysis and data-based modeling techniques. Spatiotemporally comprehensive information about the interconnections between chemistry, biology, hydrology and ecology along an entire river network collected by this project will generate datasets and modeling approaches to inform adaptive management of freshwater resources and establish guidelines for total maximum daily loads in arid land rivers. Development of novel proxy relationships correlating continuous measurements to complex environmental parameters holds great potential to transform current understanding of watershed nutrient cycling and advance freshwater biogeochemistry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported research done in collaboration with the Ricardo Gonz?lez-Pinz?n group at the University of New Mexico to better understand the biogeochemistry of arid-land rivers through the collection and analysis of water quality data, with an emphasis on nutrients (carbon, nitrogen, and phosphorus). Nutrients play important roles in aquatic ecosystems, including controlling microbial activity, affecting drinking water quality, and linking terrestrial and oceanic nutrient pools.  Because of these important roles, it is essential that we understand how nutrients move through streams and rivers so we can predict what impacts a given change in a watershed (e.g., agricultural or urban development, or changes in rainfall/snowpack) will have on downstream ecosystems. 
            We conducted research in the Jemez River and Rio Grande watersheds in New Mexico, where limited water resources are stretched thinner by fluctuating snowpack, increasing demands from end-users, and ecological flow requirements. We deployed technologically advanced water quality sensors as a network from the headwaters of the Jemez River down to the main stem of the Rio Grande along gradients of elevation, vegetation, land use, and discharge. In addition to field data, we conducted regular tracer experiments to understand how microbial communities in streams interact with available nutrients throughout seasons and across stream orders. In the headwaters of the Jemez River, we found that the amount of snow in a given year is the primary driver of anoxic (lack of oxygen) conditions in the winter that are hard on aquatic life, and that rapid biogeochemical processing occurs over relatively small spatial scales throughout the year. In the Rio Grande, we utilized high-resolution data to capture monsoon storm events, and found that storm pulses originating from urban areas were associated with much higher oxygen demand driven by nutrient enrichment, which is also of concern to downstream aquatic life. Further, we tracked nutrient inputs to the Rio Grande from a wastewater treatment plant, and established when and where nutrients were being processed in the river and adjacent irrigation ditches, and provided recommendations for how the system could be improved to 1) more effectively deliver nutrients to agricultural fields, and 2) minimize nutrient-driven damage to receiving waters. 
            We also pushed the boundaries of field biogeochemistry by developing two technologies that make it easier to characterize events (e.g., tracer studies, or storms) across a wide range of aquatic environments, and improve aquatic sensor performance by autonomously filtering water prior to data collection. In collaboration with my advisor and colleagues from Italy, we quantified error associated with a smart reactive tracer of microbial activity in streams to help future researchers better utilize this tool by understanding its limitations. Through another collaboration, we published a simple yet effective statistical method for deriving meaning from complex environmental time-series, including driver-response relationships and regime shifts. Over the life of the award, we presented our findings to the broader scientific community through three published papers and many presentations at local, national, and international conferences. Three additional manuscripts conveying the findings of research made possible by this award are in review for publication, and four more are in preparation. 
            Safe-guarding water quality is a priority concern for water managers and regulators, and directly related to public health (i.e., access to potable water). Findings from this award provide new tools and statistical approaches to understand how urban development, water management, and climate change impact water quality in arid-land rivers. In turn, research products will be useful to help the management and regulation communities abide by federal guidelines, and protect drinking water security and, ultimately, public health.
